comments.commentBody: Today I talked via Skype with a dear friend in Lebanon. Ten years ago my friend was deported in the middle of the night from a Michigan county jail after having been held in solitary confinement for 16 of the 19 months he was detained. Although he was never officially charged, an unintentional visa violation was the only "crime" the Justice Department could prove. My friend's experience taught me that our government can do pretty much what it wants with persons who are not American citizens. Once deported, there is no serious chance at appeal and no one to speak for you. My friend says he learned grace under pressure from the experience. I learned that the American system of justice does not insure justice for all.

Some of the commentators have answered the substance of this article.

Let me point to its faulty method. The argument is based on an ad hoc assumption, namely that estate and progressive taxes are based and must be based on "shared sacrifice". If we do not grant this assumption, the whole argument collapses. Other commentators have supplied other criteria: all linked to the idea of justice common to all serious moral philosophy from Aristotle to Rawls. Even in the version of equality of opportunity justice requires relatively equal starting points in life, something we are very far from today.

So what about the results of the study that estates taxes are falling everywhere? There can be many reasons for this, mainly political and ideological. The decline of the need for shared sacrifice is a far fetched reason, that bears no scrutiny. I note only one point: in order to guarantee decent living standards for the poorest among us, namely justice, there is a great deal of need for shared sacrifice even in the United States. But that need in itself will not reverse the trend. Only politics, different than that of the two authors can do that.

"We'll agree to stop scheduling games in Colorado in March when [other] nations stop scheduling games . . . at 10,000 feet altitude in cities with air so polluted you can eat it with a spoon . . . ."

That's exactly the way all this works, and it exactly identifies how important each side views these advantages to be. I remember that a U.S. Soccer official mentioned, a few years ago, that they had offered Mexico's soccer federation a deal: schedule Mexico's World Cup qualifying home match against the U.S. for a low-altitude venue, such as Monterrey, and the U.S. would agree to host their home match qualifier against Mexico in the Rose Bowl, or perhaps in Dallas. The Mexicans responded, Thanks, but no.

Think about it: Mexico rejected the opportunity to schedule an away qualifier, at their biggest CONCACAF rival, in a venue that would be tantamount to a home game, with their fans very likely constituting more than half the attendance. *That's* how much they value the advantages of the atmosphere, in both senses -- the thin, hot, polluted air, and the cacophonous emotional ambiance -- of Azteca.

I'd put more blame on the destruction of traditional credit standards (e.g., down payments and income documentation) that George W. Bush demanded from his regulators at his October 15, 2002 White House Conference on Increasing Minority Homeownership. Bush denounced old-fashioned prudence as standing in the doorway of racial equality in homeownership, a demand that, among others, Angelo Mozilo immediately echoed.

Steve Sailer is right.  Bush acted like a liberal in this instance and his liberalism had a lot to do with the onset of the housing crisis.   That does not mean that liberalism is necessarily wrong, merely that on occasion liberalism too needs a dose of reality checking.

Even the policies of Bush on minority housing had virtually nothing to do with the crisis. The lax lending standards were due to "advances" in securitization and risk management that allowed mortgage originators to pass on mortgages to others and thus not have to bear the credit risk themselves. Credit ratings agencies (which are paid by issuers not investors) then slapped AAA ratings on these piles of risky mortgages. Financial institutions relied on these ratings and faulty risk management in their search for yield, and leveraged up to earn bigger returns. Freed from concerns of default, banks could farm out mortgage origination to mortgage brokers who are paid on commissions and have an incentive to sign up as many people as possible, regardless of whether they can actually afford the payments. These brokers are regulated at the state level and were not closely policed, leading to buses such as liar loans. The wide availability of mortgages coupled with too low interest rates courtesy of Greenspan fed a property bubble that snowballed. Traders at financial institutions piled into these mortgages because they are playing with other people's money and have an incentive to take a lot of risk. In short there was systematic risk almost everywhere, mostly due to inadequate regulation.

Your observation is right on, but there are some additional important observations:
1) The stepped-up basis is a huge benefit, cost-free, to estates below the exemption limit. The estate has to be quite large before the estate tax makes up for the stepped-up basis savings.
2) The door to cheat on cost basis reporting has long been open, for inherited and ordinary assets, and only recently is an effort being made to shut it. Financial institutions are only now being required to report the cost basis of investments. Many investments to which capital gains apply are outside financial institutions (for example, fine art) and therefore cost basis is reported on an honor system basis. In the past, only the fear of audit prevented people from lying about their cost basis of investments.

There's another advantage to employing an estate tax with stepped-up basis, namely, that many of the assets in the estate simply do not have the records available to know what the original basis was. And if the records exist, for a large estate it may still be difficult and expensive to evaluate the original basis. By using the stepped-up basis as the basis for the person inheriting the assets these difficulties are bypassed.

I thought that this was one of the biggest defects of the Bush tax plan.

As someone who inherited from an estate large enough to trigger the tax, I do not think of the estate tax as an attempt to redistribute wealth. To me, it is the tax that I have paid for the stepped-up basis of the estate. The estate taxes that were paid made up for taxes on the millions of dollars of capital gains that were wiped out when my parents died.

The stepped-up basis and the inheritance tax go hand in hand. If you eliminate one, you should eliminate the other, as the Bush tax plan did. But if you eliminate the stepped-up basis, that opens the door for enormous opportunities for mistakes and out-right cheating by claiming a basis for assets which is higher than it should be.

I think the new estate tax is pretty fair, but could be tweaked.

I've heard that more is spent on compliance/planning than is generated by the tax. The $10m threshold seems fair, as only a few people will have to worry about hitting it. It should be set so only a few have to deal with it (top 1% cutoff was like $8m in net worth I think).

Indexing it makes sense, because inflation obviously increases the nominal value of the estate's property over time without increasing the real value--yet you pay tax on the nominal increase.

My favorites are the DuPont family, who first made their family fortune selling gunpowder during the revolutionary war, and the Astors, whose fortune goes back to the fur trade.

I believe it is a fine incentive to allow parents to pass on a good living to their immediate offspring. Five million should be enough for a person to live a good life even if they are unable or not disposed to earn their own way.
Beyond a few million, an inheritance is not for spending. It is for managing and controlling a capitalist empire, that is the livelihoods of other people such as employees, suppliers, customers, et.al. When a talented person earns a great fortune she usually does so by delivering great value to society (that is the basis of the market system.). It might be better to redistribute that un-spendable wealth in society to those who show the talent to run it for the continued benefit of society.

The estate tax provides a strong social safety value to release substantial wealth from control by a few and to free it up for diversification of capital investments in the country. What we have seen since 1980 is the increasing concentration of wealth by tax policies which concentrates more and more of the wealth subsequently created into fewer and fewer hands. We were told by advocates of lower taxes and of decreasing estate taxes that the additional money in the hands of the most wealthy would translate into great and more diversified investments and business ventures that would raise up all. The results have shown something much different. The actual results have effectively reduced the tax revenues needed to support our public infrastructure and services as well as to restrict where capital is available for innovations and new businesses according to the preferences of fewer people. As fewer people become more wealth most people become less and less prosperous and social mobility as well as the growth of the domestic economy slowly decrease.

In reply to Dora, we all want to leave something for our children. The question is what advantage is there--either to society or to ourselves--to passing massive amounts of wealth from one generation to the next? Will it make one's children better people? Will it make them more productive? Will $10 million feed them better than $5 million (much less $1 billion vs. $500 million)? The few true family businesses out there, where control is still in the hands of the family members and the children are trained to and intend to take over running the business, can cover their anticipated estate tax liability through taking out universal or whole life insurance policies, or they can simply work it out with the IRS, which accepts payment over time for estate tax liability on a going family concern. There's no reason I can think of for allowing large fortunes to remain intact generation after generation other than one's own self-aggrandizing need to perpetuate a dynasty.

In counting the various ways our income is taxed, remember to add the biggest income tax for 50% or more of the population: payroll taxes. Yes, folks, Social Security, Disability Insurance, and Hospital Insurance taxes may be dedicated to their respective programs, but they are income taxes.

"Why should the next generation inherit? They did nothing to earn that wealth other than be born, and during their growing years had lots of advantages in food, education, medical care, etc. that so many other Americans can't even imagine."

This logic could be applied to all Americans since wealth is relative and on a spectrum - One man's wealth is another man's poverty. And aren't Americans vastly more wealthy than the poor in third world nations? It also presumes that the state becomes the ultimate owner of all capital and related decisions on how its spent when someone dies.

I suspect Mary does not imagine she would be taxed today and would object to an estate tax that applies to her. She would be come even more strident if ALL of her assets were taken by they government when she dies. But after all, what did potential recipients of her estate do to earn it?

To argue that estate taxes are necessary or fair only in actual wars ignores the fact that our national budget continues to carry huge military expenses and increasing amounts of support for the ever growing population of seniors -- both are enormous drains on the budget and must be paid for. Both state and national governments face enormous costs for rebuilding our infrastructure and again, carig for seniors.

Those who complain that estate taxes hit assets that have already been subject to income taxes as that wealth was earned, ignore the fact that our income is taxed over and over and over again during our lifetimes -- gasoline tax, sales tax, real estate tax, state, local and federal income taxes, liquor taxes, highway and bridge tolls, postage stamps, car registration fees, courthouse filig fees, use taxes, extra state tax on my evening gowns (go figure that one out), and who knows what else we are not even aware of. So estate taxes are not the only taxes paid on what was once one's income.

Why should the next generation inherit? They did nothing to earn that wealth other than be born, and during their growing years had lots of advantages in food, education, medical care, etc. that so many other Americans can't even imagine. Why can't each generation earn their own wealth, to enjoy during their lifetimes, and then pay it back to society in the form of significant estate taxes?
